awd_titl_txt: Autonomous Control of Indoor Climate for Commercial Buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
Buildings account for 45 percent of the total energy consumption in the United States (U.S.), and maintaining indoor climate, which includes heating, cooling, and ventilation, accounts for approximately half of that energy consumption. A low-cost option for reducing building energy usage is intelligent climate control, moving away from the prevalent "design for steady-state conditions" philosophy into one that exploits the constantly changing conditions a building operates in due to its occupants and the weather. The potential for intelligent climate control has been recognized for many years, especially for commercial buildings that have the requisite sensors and actuators. In particular, control algorithms that make decisions using real-time optimization have been shown to be highly promising. In spite of its promise, such "model-optimization" based control technologies have not been widely adopted by industry. The reason for this lack of translation to practice is the lack of autonomy of existing algorithms. Not only do they require expert human involvement in model creation, which have to be tuned for each building manually, they do not provide guarantees about the quality of real-time decisions. Addressing these weaknesses will lead to the wider adoption of intelligent building climate control technologies, which will contribute to the technological edge U.S. industries enjoy, and reduce the nation's energy usage.

This research project seeks to make model+optimization based control of commercial buildings autonomous, thereby aiding wider adoption of such advanced technologies. The approach is to engineer both the modeling and optimization phases specifically for autonomy. The modeling approach is purely data driven so that it can be easily applied to any building. By using recently developed machine learning methods that guarantee certain beneficial model properties (e.g., stability), models can be updated over time purely from data without ever requiring a human expert to check the quality or suitability of the models. Similarly, the optimization problem is made convex by a choice of linear models so that real-time decision making can occur reliably without the optimizer getting stuck in a local minima or failing to converge. The reduction in accuracy due to the restriction to linear models is ameliorated by re-learning models over time, which is made possible by the autonomous data-driven nature of the model fitting algorithms. Finally, special care is taken to ensure that humidity and latent heat considerations, which are critical to hot humid climates, are taken into account both in the modeling and real-time optimization phases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Buildings account for 45 percent of the total energy consumption in the United States (U.S.), and heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems in buildings account for approximately half of that energy consumption. A low-cost option for reducing building energy usage – and carbon emissions - is intelligent control of indoor climate. Such a control system would adjust HVAC equipment operation in real time through on-line optimization. In spite of its promise, such "real-time optimization" based control technologies have not been widely adopted by the building automation industry. The reason is the lack of autonomy of existing algorithms. Existing methods require expert humans to tune the optimization model for each building manually, and they do not provide guarantees about the quality of real-time decisions.

Addressing these weaknesses will lead to the wider adoption of intelligent building climate control technologies, which will contribute to the technological edge U.S. industries enjoy, and reduce the nation's energy usage.

This research project seeks to make model+optimization based control of commercial buildings’ HVAC systems autonomous, thereby aiding wider adoption of such advanced technologies. The approach is to engineer both the modeling and optimization phases specifically for autonomy. The modeling approach is purely data driven so that it can be easily applied to any building. By using recently developed machine learning methods that guarantee certain beneficial model properties (e.g., stability), models can be updated over time purely from data without ever requiring a human expert to check the quality or suitability of the models. Similarly, the optimization problem is made convex by a choice of linear models so that real-time decision making can occur reliably without the optimizer getting stuck in a local minima or failing to converge. The reduction in accuracy due to the restriction to linear models is ameliorated by re-learning models over time, which is made possible by the autonomous data-driven nature of the model fitting algorithms. Finally, special care is taken to ensure that humidity and latent heat considerations, which are critical to hot humid climates, are taken into account both in the modeling and real-time optimization phases.

The project made significant advancements to the development of autonomous optimal control methods for HVAC systems. We developed Model Predictive Control (MPC) techniques for HVAC systems that have an outer on-line learning loop that automatically updates models from data, without requiring any intervention from human experts. This was made possible by the development of on-line system identification methods that come with formal guarantees on the properties of the model they identify. We also developed MPC techniques that can handle humidity and latent heat in a principled manner irrespective of whether the outdoor climate is dry or humid, a capability prior methods do not have. These techniques are expected to dramatically reduce the cost of deployment of advanced control techniques to the HVAC sector and thus drive translation to practice. The results from the research led to the publication of several top-tier journal papers and peer-reviewed conference papers, and a U.S. patent application. Finally, we developed techniques to characterize flexibility of HVAC loads to act as virtual batteries that can help integrated volatile solar and wind energy and thus reduce the cost of renewable integration.

The project outcomes also exceeded their initial goals. Supported by a data-science supplement, we extended the scope of the project to model-free control techniques, which can learn optimal control actions purely from data without needing a simplified model. By cutting down the time and cost necessary for model calibration, model-free methods may drive adoption of advanced HVAC control systems by industry even faster.

Apart from research results, the project contributed significantly to graduate and undergraduate education and professional development of the students. The project partially supported four PhD students, one of whom is a woman. Three undergraduate students also conducted independent research related to this project. All the graduate students published high impact journal articles and presented conference papers, learning effective written and oral communication skills along the way.
